I found the Chinese version to be less salty and lighter, the Korean versions I have tried have more of a dark, hoisin  flavor. I was pleasantly surprised that the squishy noodles were home-made. They don't cheap out on the meat sauce, there is tons of the good stuff, but it manages to never overpower those noodles.

Found this place on yelp and went for dinner last night.  It's a fairly small restaurant with 30 some seats so expect to wait if you come on a busy day.  

We ordered beef noodle soup, scallion pancakes, beef chow fan, and mango smoothie.  We were pleasantly surprised that all the dishes and smoothie were delicious!!  We loved the smoothie and scallion pancakes so much that we ordered another to go.  We would definitely recommend it to anyone who goes to the Chinatown in Philly for good (Taiwanese) food.

My parents are from Taiwan and they were pretty impressed with this restaurant. I always get the beef noodle soup and it never disappoints. My girlfriend gets the Indonesian lo mein (spicy) which is hella good. The service is great and you can't beat the price if you're in need of some Taiwanese food. This has been one of my regular spots I go to and I highly recommend it!
The service was terrible and the food was worse. It's seems are to believe that you could eat this bad of food in China town!!

Based on an adventurous kick my bf had and yelp reviews, I payed a visit to these friendly folks.

Order: scallion pancakes, chicken and cashew combo platter with wonton soup (mine), shrimp pan fried noodles (bfs order) 

Pros:
1. wonton soup was amazing! i looooove wonton soup! the broth was AMAZING! 
2. the spring roll that came with my meal was probably the best spring roll ive had in a long time! it even had whole shrimp!
3. food came out so fast! i didnt even finish my first cup of tea
4. staff is really nice, not annoying and bugging you every 2 minutes to check if youre ok. they alllll say bye when you leave, i feel like im leaving a friends house.
5. cheap! our total was $24! we had so much food!
6. the random one... i got a plate with compartments, you know like when youre 5 yrs old and everything is separated on your plate? yea one of those, i was waiting to see elmo on the bottom... 

Cons:
1. the dining area was small and kind of awkard... the table we got was uncomfortable. the man behind me kept moving back and forth on the booth i would get launched forward and back like every 15 seconds. it was so annoying
2. it was so quiet, i felt like i had to whisper...
3. we tried the pancakes bc everyone said they were amazing, all i have to say is ive had better. sorry.
4. no elmo on my plate =(

This place is a true gem in Philadelphia's China Town.  I ate here for the first time today and ordered the fish fillet in black bean sauce with a side of shrimp friend rice, and both were AMAZING! The portions are large and the prices are better than comparable places in China Town.

They have gone done in the last few years.

We come in and they are initially attentive, but after ordering drinks and appetizers, they leave and never come back to take our order for entrees AND we were the only customers sitting in the restaurant at the time, Da FUQ.

We kindly paid left and we will probably not go again, I've told many people about this place over the years, I do not think I will ever recommend the Empress Garden again.

I am really sad about that.

P. S. The dirty mop smell does not help.

My favorite dish is the eggplant! Beef noodles is pretty good as well :)

Can't wait to try the scallion pancakes!

I came here with my parents during lunch hours on a weekday. It wasn't too busy, so we were seated right away. Wait time for the food wasn't long either, about 10 minutes. I ordered the tomatoes and beef over rice. I thought it would just be tomatoes and beef with rice, but it's actually eggs and tomatoes plus beef over rice. It was delicious! The portions are pretty generous, definitely enough to fill a person up. And it's pretty cheap too, only around $7. For the amount and quality of the food I got, I'd say it's definitely worth it. Would come back again and try some of the other dishes.

Food was delicious server took a while to get to me. I ordered the shrimp with lobster sauce which was good. The portion was good as well. Was a bit disappointed because they were doing the lunch speacial.

Let's start by saying Empress Garden doesn't impress me much. 
I was told by a lot of online review from Taiwanese that the food here is great and genuine Taiwanese food. I cannot comment on the genuineness since I'm not a Taiwanese. But based on the Taiwan style food I had before this is below my expectation. 
I had the beef noodle and fried dumplings. Beef noodle is of pretty good quality. The soup and the beef are tasty, but the noodle is not so good: it breaks easily and tastes too soft. The dumplings, well I can have dumplings of that quality at any food truck around Philly. 
Maybe there are other things I can order that taste better. I'll probably give it another try but I won't be inviting my friends and telling them this is a great restaurant.

It was good with some things and others not so good.  My wife is a die hard Taiwanese food lover and she was scared to eat some of the things (oyster pancake).  Not to happy when stinky tofu was not on the menu, but that was a plus for me.  Chow fun was good, not the best.  Corn soup was just egg drop with some corn and chicken added to it.  Pan fried noodles was surprisingly a good pick for the kids.  Beef noodles was overcome by fillers, totally not necessary, it would have been better without the extra stuff.  Total hole in the wall, but if you want to go somewhere you wife will never find you with your girlfriend this is the place for you.

Mind you, I haven't eaten Chinese food in years. I was in Philly and, on the spur of the moment, decided to pick some up; bad idea. I checked my cell for the best restaurants for egg too young; my favorite. By a process of elimination, I ended up here. I knew I'd made a big mistake as soon as I tried to spoon the sauce. It looked like plastic, flowed in globs, and tasted like something out of a rusty can. 
I really thought twice before giving it to my dog.

Nice little place in Chinatown with good authentic food. The service is good, especially the one lady who is super cheerful and enthusiastic. If you don't know what to order, you can ask your waiter. I recommend what is popular there, which is the Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup. Stay away from your typical takeout food and try other things on the menu that you you're not familiar with. Take some risk. :)

Empress Garden is my favorite Taiwanese restaurant in Philly and the cure for my perpetual homesickness. I order takeout here every week via the Yelp app and it's the most convenient thing ever. My order is ready for pick-up within 20-40 minutes (40 if I order the three-cup chicken) and it is always packed very neatly with ample utensils (food never spills on the ride home). I have also dined in at the restaurant and the customer service and waitstaff are really courteous. 

In my humble Taiwanese American opinion, here's a list of the restaurant's best dishes: three cup chicken, Chinese broccoli, Taiwanese meatball, snow pea leaves, pork belly over rice, and oyster pancake.

Thank you yelp for finding us a Taiwanese restaurant in Philadelphia.  Food was excellent.  Definitely not americanized, but we ordered off the chinese language menu.  We did takeout and a few days later ate there.  There are definitely some foods that won't travel well.  If you eat in, get the oyster pancake, scallion pancake, and pork ribs (dry rub deep fried).  Some of the other dishes are saucy - my favorite was the beef and chinese broccoli.
After I gave it another try I feel this is only a place to grab lunch if you happen to be in front of it and don't wanna walk any further. I won't go again.

I wanted to order something off the Chinese menu, but since I do not speak or read Chinese, the menu was of little help. I tried to explain the dish I was after, Chicken with dried tofu noodles and the waitress didn't understand what I was talking about, so I was forced to stick to the lunch specials. I saw the usual American fare, and so I chose the Chicken with Broccoli (7.50 with tax). It wasn't that tasty honestly. The hot and sour soup was okay, but the fried rice tasted like corn meal. 

The waitress was really nice though.

Visa accepted here. No minimums.

Food Quality/Taste = 2 Stars
Portion Size Given Price = 3 Stars
Price = 3 Stars
Service = 2 Stars (no water refills)
Experience with Staff = 4 Stars

We have been trying out different spots around Chinatown to mix up our usual routine of constantly going to get pho or ramen. Their beef noodle soup definitely held up against our usual favorites! Nice broth, great chewy noodles, and hearty pieces of tender beef. It wasn't spicy really, but I thoroughly enjoyed it and drank every last drop.

We also got scallion pancakes, which were a great deal for $3.50. They came out hot and crispy with a vinegar based dripping sauce. The two entrees we went with were the three cup chicken and salt and pepper pork chops. The chicken was INSANELY flavorful and was probably our favorite thing. There are small bones so be careful, but the meat is so soft and full of savory, garlicky goodness it was hard to put down. Definitely get some white rice with it for all the sauce. The salt and pepper pork chops were crispy but moist on the inside, and topped off with sautéed garlic and peppers. We had already eaten half the portion by the time we had taken the picture!

The service was super fast, and the food came out quick as well. The interior is small but not cramped and we'll definitely be back!

I have been here several times and will recommend it to anyone looking for a place to eat authentic Taiwanese food. The scallion pancakes, indonesian chicken curry, beef noodle soup and ma po tofu are just some of the great dishes this place serves. Its one of my favorite places to eat in Chinatown!

Pretty good and authentic food.  We went with people who were able to read and order off of the Chinese menu so we had the "good stuff".  I saw some tourists ordering at the other table and they got the typical fried rice and egg roll combos, which did not look to exciting.  Our food included the fried oysters in a scrambled egg type form, Beef noodle soup, seafood soup of some sort and a fried sizzling tofu dish (which was super salty).  The place was kind of dirty inside and reminded me of China, but the waitress was really nice.

The good: the pork fried rice is pretty good. 

The bad: 
- This was a delivery order. They didn't seal or wrap our containers, so most of my soup was at the bottom of the bag, mixed with sloshing General Tso sauce from another container. All containers were soggy and breaking, my spring roll was soggy. 
- The spring roll is all cabbage, with two micro shrimp. 
- They mixed my chicken right with the sweet and sour sauce, so also soggy. 
- Not enough chicken in the General Tso order, not  even enough to cover the bottom of the container. 
- Very strange sauce with the dumplings, horrible after taste.

Empress Garden is a nice little restaurant right next to the Chinatown arch, unassuming in the outside, and quaint once inside. The restaurant was clean and surprisingly busy for an early dinner. 

We ordered the friend dumplings and the general tso's chicken, both of which were delicious and fried to perfection. We also ordered the bubble tea, which was excellent!! Much cheaper than the other bubble tea places nearby and the bubbles were soft and chewy.  

We recommend trying if you're in the area!

Been back multiple times. Always a good comfort Taiwanese meal with oyster pancakes, scallion pancakes, and san bei ji (3 cup chicken). 

Consistently good, flavorful food and service (err....not so flavorful but still good)

Although the oyster pancake is more "fried" than would be on the streets/night markets in taiwan, it is still very close to the consistency/starchiness of what one could get there. 

Also, the frequently have our favorite chinese veggies, dou miao (snow pea tips) and kong xing cai (open stem ("heart") greens), whether they're on the menu or not. :) This really is one of our go-to places in Chinatown.

I've been wanting to eat here for awhile and so glad I finally got a chance.  The restaurant is small but clean with good service.

We ordered the following:
salt and pepper wings - pretty average
Taiwanese meatballs - interesting. It's like a mochi type covering beef mix. Not a fan of the sauce.  
scallion pancakes - really liked these. Nice and chewy and good dipping sauce
oyster pancakes - I enjoyed these but same sauce as the meatballs.  Will ask for the sauce on the side next time.
Peking noodle (ja jian mien) - really liked this dish.  The noodles were cooked well and the sauce was really good
Minced pork and eggplant dish was flavorful and delicious
3 cup chicken - I wasn't expecting much but chicken was really tender and sauce was good - I didn't have a huge issue with bones as mentioned in other reviews
Salt and pepper pork chops - one of the faves of the bunch.  This was so good. 

Next time, I'd like to try the Indonesian fried rice and mapotofu
I wish I had gotten a little minced pork on my pork chop rice platter, but otherwise it was tasty!

Why is it that the first time around the food is always good?? Went there again for dinner and to be honest, this place was gross!! They did,kt have the spicy pork belly, the pork chop noodle soup was very bland and also the oyster pancake was disgusting. All I tasted was cornstarch!

Empress Garden is a small shop on N. 10th Street in Chinatown, Philly, that changed hands about a year ago.  The original owner (the "Empress"), was a sterling hostess and stunning beauty who ran her house efficiently and with admirable warmth.  The food had a Taiwanese and Indonesian orientation, but also had the standard American/Chinese dishes for those who preferred them.  Their fruit drinks were freshly squeezed, and it had a strong following. 

I returned after an absence of a few years, and my first run with the new operation.  While the menu was basically the same as before, the actual plates coming from the kitchen seemed to have lost a bit of their edge.  We ordered Scallion Pancakes, Curry Chicken with Onions, Salt & Pepper Pork Chops, Orange Beef and Sautéed String Beans.  A lot for the three of us to consume, but we were looking forward to bring the balance home.  

While the Scallion Pancakes were good, they are certainly returned to the norm, and were not as exceptional as remembered.  The Chicken dish had the right taste and fresh chicken, but the Onions were harder than desired, and thus tended to dominate the dish.  The S & P Pork Chops had been a wonderful platter in the past, but this day the breading and meat was over-deep fried, making it tougher in the bite, and less enjoyable in the chew.  Disappointing.  The Orange Beef was the best thing on our table, with a nice spicy, not overly gloopy, sauce.  It was fun to eat even with the orange peel in its soft non-burnt condition.  Finally, the Veggies were fine with a light Garlic finish.  

The meal was satisfactory, but not what I hoped for based on recollection.  Empress Garden was now just another Chinatown restaurant with a fair kitchen and price, but nothing to make it outstanding.

I've been here MANY times.  As far as I know, it's the only place that offers decent Taiwanese dishes in Philly, though of course it doesn't compare to California.

What's good here:

*Scallion pancakes
*3 Cups Chicken
*Fried pork chop (pretty decent)

Additionally, I think their fried pot stickers are decent along with their beef noodle soup.  These aren't my favorite here but admittedly I have high standards since I grew up in LA.
Horrible service, don't get what you order, and don't get a lot of food. Greasy and disgusting.

Food was ok.  Smaller portions than I am used to. No tea brought out, no duck sauce or fortune cookies. Had to ask for silverware.
Took a while to get someone to come and pack up some leftovers in our party of three. They don't come to refill or ask if you want anything else.  Found a long hair on a napkin which they are very skimpy with, the napkins not the hair.

The five stars may seem generous but this place wins for simple dishes that are fresh and tasty, large portions enough for leftovers, and friendly service with no credit card minimum! Now that's a combination you rarely see in Chinatown. 

There's one dish that I love here and it is the Peking noodles with meat sauce. I used to come and get it to go all the time. The to-go comes in two separate containers - one of just the noodles and one of the sauce (a sauce with diced meat, green beans, and tofu). This isn't the traditional zhajianmien from Beijing but it's so good! It sounds simple but each slurp is delicious and comforting. You're definitely carbaloading with this dish but it easily divides into 2 reasonably portioned meals. 

A couple other dishes we like are the Taiwanese noodle soup & beef chow fun. Again, the flavors aren't complex but are reminiscent of meals from a home kitchen. Cheers to the home comfort & simplicity.

You'll not see the resto sign if you not really looking..
Small resto..sort of like cafe with only maybe 7-8 seat..
But they food are Awesomely Delicious!
If you guys like Spicy (like me Because i'm Asian ;))
You should try Nasi Goreng Indo/Indonesian Spicy Fried Rice and Bakmie Goreng indo/Indonesian Fried Noddle...Delish
Price Range around $8-$10 
Reasonable i guess for their portion is enough to share for 2!
Two Thumbs Up..if you go there..find the Indonesian Waitress name IDA..for that 3 the best Indonesian menu
Their Tahu Goreng/fried Tofu is delish too!

The worst ever. If you can't make the three cup chicken right. How dare you call yourself a Taiwanese restaurant! Unbelievably terrible. Should rate Zero if I have that option.
Updates: Receive a very unprofessional and insulting personal message from the owner. He called me Crazy just because this honest negative review! Unbelievable!!!Please, it's not the right way to do business. Btw, is any way to escalate the personal insults to Yelp?

Further Updates: Got more threatening messages from the owner. First, please get a basic understanding of the legal definition of rumor from your lawyer! If you are going to threaten and insult everyone who leave a honest negative review, I really question your professional ethics, if you have any. Second, People use Yelp as a platform to express their honest feelings about their consumer experiences. You have no right to insult and threaten customers because of criticism. I'm not afraid of your threats. Bring it on! Bro! Why are you so afraid that this review is going to affect your business? Let me guess, did I tell the truth so you got scared? If you got confidence in your cuisine, why are you acting like this?
Last and not least, stop the harassment, or I will take all the necessary legal actions regarding your insults and threats.
BTW, never thought that my first Yelp review will become this ridiculous drama. Share my experiences with all who yelp. Hope it gives you guys an opportunity to stay away from places those aren't worth your time.

FINAL UPDATE: So sick of receiving another harassing messages from the owner. Never apologize for his inappropriate wording and insults. Will definitely bring legal actions. People should know how to behave!
Not bad, but not great. The place is small so expect to be close to other guests. The food was just ok. Nothing really impressed me.

Look, I'm a Taiwanese and I don't think the entrees were very Taiwanese, but the food was still excellent!

Unfortunately my family did not order any Taiwanese snacks and instead ordered two entree dishes: three cup chicken and Hakka-style tofu pot. While these were certainly Taiwanese dishes, the tastes were more like Chinese cuisine. That doesn't mean the food was bad though, but the three cup chicken was absolutely delicious!

The moment the large clay pot of three cup chicken arrived, our table was engulfed with its luring aroma. I could not stop myself from continuously taking pieces after pieces after the dish arrived! This mildly spicy entree was addictingly flavorful. So glad I had leftovers to relive the moment again later that night!

Great food, cheap options, large portions, friendly service, clean interior...If you are in the Philly Chinatown, Empress Garden should be your top choice!

Our meal was less than satisfactory. The tea was cold, my shrimp with walnuts was heavily breaded and partially cold, the rice was lukewarm with burned portions possibly from the bottom of the pot. My husband had pork with black bean sauce which was fine and warm. 
During the meal the staff stood just out of the main dining area and talked loudly the entire time we were eating. It was distracting, unpleasant and less than helpful. The restaurant was empty so it's not like they were overloaded with customers. Not sure where 4 stars came from but it does not reflect on our experience. It's been a long time since we've had such a poor meal.

So... There's a big button on Empress Garden's page in the Yelp app that says "Order Delivery". DON'T DO THAT. The online ordering system itself is seamless, and supposedly your food gets delivered from some service called Dining In Philadelphia or delivery.com. Now I've never ordered food from this restaurant and this delivery service and its vague names seemed a little sketchy, but we were hungry.  We ordered ma po tofu and chicken for delivery at 6:45pm. At 8:00pm, I called the number in the email confirmation to check on the order. The number led to a voicemail system for the administrative office of the delivery service (under yet another vague name). Hmmm. So I called the restaurant and reached a lady who yelled, "You pick up!!" a bunch of times as I tried to inquire about our food order. Then she hung up on me. Then I called some other number in the confirmation email and reached an actually very nice lady who kept me on hold for a while as she tried to call the restaurant (probably got yelled at), and then finally returned to my call and cancelled the order. Fine. It was about 8:30 at this point. We made quesadillas and went to sleep. 9:30pm.... Phone rings repeatedly. It's the delivery guy! He's outside! Almost 3 hours after we ordered! I tell him we ordered hours ago and had since cancelled the order. He is dismayed and says no one told him. A few minutes later he calls back and says he talked to someone and we can have the food anyway. I said thanks but we ate already.
Great food! Scallion pancakes for an app, very good. General Tso's chicken, chicken chow fun, 3 cup chicken- all solid options!

Love this place. It's my newfound favorite. 

First, my Taiwanese friend recommend it to me, then my HK friend also recommend this restaurant to me. So we thought, let's give it a shot. The place looks unappealing from outside but if you're looking for good authentic Chinese food, this is the place to be. It's clean and small, so large party is not recommended. 

We are not sure what to order since we don't speak nor read Chinese at all. We also don't want to eat just an ordinary American Chinese food. The waitress: Ida is Indonesian. lucky me, so she recommend me the good authentic food over there. She's also great with my American friend and speak English very well. 

My favorite so far is shredded beef with tofu and bamboo shoot, the fried noodle (there're many kinds of them, ask them to recommend you, all of them that i tried were good), the noodle like Dave H recommended (note: it's C62 in the menu not C71, although C71 is also good). We took home the Taiwanese beef noodle soup and wasn't too impressed, so we may have to eat there. The chicken in the hot pot is also delicious. 

If you want authentic Chinese food, ask them to recommend you, don't go by the menu because the English menu is pretty much American standard Chinese food. 

The price is also very good as it ranges from $6.95 to $8.95. I haven't tried their fish but I will next time I go there with more friends (not just the two of us). 

Ooh and the fruit juice is to die for. It's very good,fresh and big tall glass only cost $2.95.

We ordered 7 dishes, and was still hungry afterwards because the food wasn't very good, it was either too salty or bland. Since none of our food was good, we did not order more. 

Hot & Sour Soup - 5
I had always loooove hot & sour soup so it's not hard to make me happy with this soup. 

Spicy Beef Tenon - 1
It was nothing but salty. Waaaaay toooooo salty! Not spicy at all. It was inedible. It was "house recommended" but I wouldn't recommend this to anyone. 

Fish ball soup - 3
Small boiled white fish balls. Compared to the other food I had here, this is edible. 

Ma Po Tofu - 2
This dish was supposed to be "house recommended" and this restaurant's "special" dish as it is written up on their chalkboard but there was barely any taste to it. It wasn't spicy at all. 

Beef & Beans - 1 
Awfully salty! It tastes like they soak them in salt and served it like that. 

3 Bui Gai (Chicken) - 1 
This is also "house recommended," this restaurant's "special" dish, and a traditional Taiwanese dish. This is a Taiwanese cuisine restaurant so we expected it to be good. Not only did it not meet our expectation, it tasted awful! It was plain SALTY! So bad! It's like they didn't mix it well, one chicken was super sweet, the other was ridiculously salty. 

Gon Chow Au Hor (Dry fried stirred flat noodles) - 2
It was bland. Didn't taste like anything but since we had so much salty food, this was saving my life. 

I feel bad but I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone. If you are a tourist like me and you're wondering around Philadelphia's Chinatown looking for tasty food... There's no tasty food here.

Best Taiwanese beef noodle soup in Philly Chinatown in my opinion given the quantity, quality, and price. One of the few Chinatown restaurants that also offers traditional Jia Jiang Mien, which is minced pork tofu and scallions over noodles, in generous portions.  The restaurant is small for large groups but a great place to eat for groups of 1-4.  Accepts cash and card (minimum $10 or $15) which is a plus if you are short on cash.

This restaurant in simple terms is nothing out of the ordinary, it's similar to other Chinese style restaurants in the area. The staff that work there are average and the food is average. The portions are a good size both times I've been here.  We ordered the sweet and sour chicken and as an appetizer the scallion pancakes.

The scallion pancakes came out first so that was good, it comes with a sauce which compliments the dish. The sweet and sour chicken was average, nothing to rave out. They deep fry the chicken and the sauce is a little bit to thick for my own choosing but to each it's own.  They give you free tea and water which is cool. 

The staff could've been a bit more attentive. They also seem disorganized a little bit. We had three different people come to our table to give us food or clean up our dishes. The gentlemen that works there I feel was the most professional out of the three. The prices for food is ok and I would come back here again in the future.

The dining area is a bit small but it works so not a deal breaker. There's only one bathroom I believe so that could be an issue for some. They greeted us upon walking in and we were seated immediately. Overall I gave it 3.0 stars out of 5.0. I think the service needs to improve for sure.

I came here really excited to try one of the only Taiwanese restaurants in the Philly area. I'm Taiwanese and grew up eating my mom's Taiwanese cooking, and this place was kind of disappointing. I guess it's semi-authentic, but that doesn't mean it's GOOD. I don't really get these glowing reviews. 

The beef noodle soup was fine but average. Nowhere near the best I've had. The pork chops over rice (pai gu fan) were also fine I suppose. The food in general was just okay. 

Also, my dining companion swears he saw bugs. Plural. Like, on the table AND on the floor. I don't mind a little dirtiness in a Chinese restaurant, but multiple roach-like bugs in the dining area are unacceptable. 

If you're looking for decent Taiwanese food around Philly, Han Dynasty is actually Taiwanese-owned and offers a selection of authentic Taiwanese dishes out at their suburban locations.
Love this place foods good great price and the waitress is so friendly a definite place to eat and they got combo meals to

I just finished eating here for the first time.  I read about the raving reviews of their beef noodle soup, and being as a beef noodle soup connoisseur, i had to check it out.  So I get to the restaurant, its small like most other chinatown restaurants in philly, but luckily I didnt have to wait to get seated.  I ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup, (they have another item on the menu that is beef noodle soup with vegetables, which is not what i got ).  The bowl that it came in was decently sized, not too big, not too small.  The broth was smooth and not too salty.  I would have liked more star of anis flavor, but this satisfied my craving nonetheless.  The sour lettuce, was a bit much for me, maybe put in half the amount that was given to me.  There was also specks of other vegetables like ginger, onion, etc.  The noodles themselves were very good, chewy, soft, probably home made although i cant confirm that after only one visit.  

Overall i would definitely return to this small joint, and order the same thing.  This is one of the better beef noodle soups Ive had and I'm lucky yelp pointed me in the right direction.

Lunch special about $5.25, Fried Rice, Sauteed Vegetables and Shrimp. Quite Americanized food. very disappointed. owner is sczchuan provincial refugees from China then moved to Taiwan, then to Philly.
Hands down the best overall experience I had in Philly Chinatown. Great food, great people and great service.

The Taiwanese beef noodle soup is smelling quite aromatic! Upon checking in, the waitress already wanted me to write a review! Hey, please let me taste and eat your food first!  (Or perhaps something was lost in translation?)

I'm searching for a good lunchtime takeout place.  Empress Garden was a disappointment.  $7.60 for lunchtime special, but the portion was so skimpy that I was still hungry when finished.  I also ordered white rice and received fried rice.  I'm still searching.

I went to this place afterwards and still their Taiwanese beef soups are the best, that I cannot deny so I upgrade the review. 

Cheers! 


Let me tell you my story:

I went for lunch alone in a hot Summer day. 
There was a Yelp check-in drink popped up, one of those Use Now or Save Later thing. When I asked the young waitress, she said, "you have to visit our website and put something there." Fine, I can live without free drink and a dumpling, whatever. 

BUT, I still did NOT get a water. I waited and waited.. no water. 
Waitress never came over until she brought noodle soup. 
Still NO water. 

Then, there were two white guys having lunch right beside me, like within 20 cms apart. Waitress came and REFILLED THEIR ICE WATER. Then just pass me by. HELLO? She gave every other customers a glass of ice water, except me till the end (yes, even when she brought me a check.)

I left NO tip, possibly for the first time in last 17 years and explained why she did not get the tip. 

Bye-bye-O!

Authentic Taiwanese food; good quantity, good quality, and quick service at a great price. I've tried their beef noodle soup, pork fried rice, scallion pancakes, and general tso's chicken -- all are solid options. This place is great if you're looking for a quick casual meal with good food or if you're looking for take-out! 

Also, they take credit cards, so it's really convenient.

The food is great but they have super rude employees.

I have been there a lot of times but tonight the chef came out of the kitchen staring my friend and I down, looking around the room for other customers and waving for us to leave.

We left 45 minutes before closing time so we weren't there late and that guy is a dick.

solid food here. enjoyed the taiwanese beef soup. the beef was very tender. would also recommend the garlic tofu appetizer--not very healthy, but was a very light tempura-style dish. prices are good and service was good.

The Chinese menu and the English menu are NOT the same. If you want the best dishes, be sure to ask for Three Cup Chicken, the Braised Pork Chops, and the Beef Noodle Broth. The mango and the strawberry smoothies are excellent. Do not order the ice tea, or any of the Americanized dishes you would get at PF Chang's (General Tso's Chicken, Beef with Broccoli, etc.) Prices are very reasonable. Located just a few steps from the Friendship Arch in Chinatown

This is a 5-star restaurant, but you have to know what you're doing.  I was lucky enough to visit with my Taiwanese in-laws so they could talk to the owners and get the good stuff, but as far as I could tell, there were no Taiwanese items on the English menu.

My recommendation:  Ask the server to suggest authentically Taiwanese dishes and skip the things you've heard of.  The oyster pancakes were fantastic as were the hand made noodles cooked in a stir-fry.  We were able to try so many interesting flavors and textures, before this meal I had no idea how good Taiwanese food could be.  The owner told us that the family has owned restaurants in Taiwan for many years.  Everything was great, I can't wait to make it back.
Great food, fast service, would absolutely come back!!  Loved my scallion pancake and chicken fried rice.  Great size of dish and good price!

This place knows Taiwanese Food!

Among the things of MUST GETs: 
- Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup - as others have mentioned, not too salty, perfectly seasoned, tender meats, noodles with nice bite, lots of pickled mustard greens (my favorite).  Great portion, doesn't go overboard on the star anise.  Actually, the Beef Noodle Soup here is better than most I have tried in NYC's Chinatown. 
- Porkchops over rice (Paigu fan) - these porkchops are perfectly seasoned with that five spice powder and the juicy suckers are fried in a super crispy batter and fried to perfection. 
- Jia Jian Mien (the homestyle noodles with the black bean sauce) - what I love about these noodles here is that there are plenty of bits of meat and it is saucy.  I hate it when you go to places and there is not enough meat.  And it's got some sprouts in there to give it that nice wet crunch.
- Mah Wan (massive Taiwanese vegetable dumpling?) I don't know what it is in english, but it is made of that glutinous rice and inside it is filled with assorted Taiwanese veggies and it has that pink/red sauce on it.  When I was growing up, I always called it a jellyfish, but it really has nothing to do with a jellyfish, it just kind of looks like one. The one here is GREAT.  No tuff spots in the dough.  The sauce is the perfect consistency and has great flavor and tang. Not overly sweet like some places.
- Scallion pancakes:  the ones here are crisp and thin and comes with the seasoned dipping sauce.  Delicious!

Service is super friendly.  I'm a fan and can't wait to go back!

First off, we got seated then the waitress disappeared. A while later she brought water then took our order. There was someone helping her and I asked him if the tea was complimentary and he said no. I still ordered some and 20 minutes later he brings it and it's cold. Keep in mind the table next to us had tea brought to them the instant they sat down. So ten more minutes go by and he comes back to the table. I asked for hot tea... so you guessed it more waiting for the hot tea. The food was ok but not good enough to compensate for the bad service. I won't be returning.

Beside Sang Kee Duck, this is my new favorite, go-to, Chinese/Taiwanese place in Philly! So not kidding, it's a at least once a week, will walk over half and hour through rain or snow, kind of place for me. 

Best dishes here that I stuff my face till I get food-coma are as follows: 
-chicken chow fun (no gravy. why is that even an option?) Lace it with Sriracha like you're supposed to. 
-Three Cup Chicken
-string beans or watercress 
-fried pork chops
-eggplant 
-egg drop soup

Other pros: 
-clean
-fast and friendly service
-the prices are killer good
-the fortune cookies there actually make sense
-the portions are plentiful
-the teapot of tea is fresh and good
-they don't judge you when you keep coming back to eat alone because you can't stay away from their addictive food.

I don't know how this food is rated even close to 4 stars. Unless your hammered drunk or have no tastebuds don't order. "Fried rice" isn't even friend Rice. It their regular rice with some soy sauce. General Tso is bland. I'm just really pissed order 70$ worth of food and it's just gross. Most is going to the dog or the garbage

Incredibly we can eat Taiwanese food when we travel in PA, we ask Days Inn hotel's desk what's his recommendation for restaurant, he recognized we are from Taiwan and tell us this restaurant.We ordered salt and pepper pork & beef noodle soup, they are delicious! I think I will go back to travel PA just for this restaurant!

This restaurant should be renamed because neither its quality nor service was fit for any royalty, let alone an empress. Although the restaurant was small and only three other tables were seated, we had to wait for nearly 1 hour to get our food (basically after all of the other tables have cleared out). The dishes were pretty pricey compared to some other options in this area but not very impressive tasting. Was definitely not worth the wait!

Okay here we go. This place isn't particularly expensive but it's not cheap. They skimped on the chicken in two orders, and gave one pint of rice for 2 entrees. Don't know if this was a skimp or an oversight.

Thats not enough for 1 stars....until we came across the endless hairs in our meals. Avoid this place.

I've been looking for Taiwanese food in Philly for the longest time and was excited when I heard about Empress Garden.

I've tried the Scallion Pancakes, Fried Pork Chop, and Taiwanese Stir-Fried Rice Cake. The food was good, but nothing that really impressed me. In general, I felt that the food was on the blander side. I pretty much dumped all the hot pepper oil in my dishes to make up for it. 

I heard a lot of people ordering Peking noodles for take-out. I'll try these next time.

I've passed Empress Garden more than a dozen times. It's fairly nondescript from the outside but when I finally went in, I really enjoyed the meal I had here. This is one of the few Taiwanese restaurants in Chinatown.  It has a very clean feel and one of the walls is a huge glass window that looks out onto 10th street, so there's plenty of natural light and sunshine.

I tried the Taiwanese beef noodle soup.  Just under 7 bucks, steaming hot, a very generous amount of beef, and very flavorful.  (Maybe a little too flavorful actually, I found the broth a teeny bit on the salty side)  I wouldn't have minded a little more of the veggies but still a great portion size for the price; I had leftovers for later.  My friend tried the Indonesian curry and really enjoyed it.  The curry itself was a little on the watery side, but we weren't sure if that's the nature of Indonesian curry itself or how it was prepared here.  

Best to avoid ordering from the lunch special menu even though those items, like General Tsao's, may sound more familiar to those who don't know a whole lot about Taiwanese cuisine, b/c those are distinctly Americanized dishes. In fact, my friend was originally going to order the Hunan chicken lunch special and the waitress actually asked if she was sure, adding that those are Americanized dishes.  

Obviously if you know Chinese, now's the time to bust it out with the waitresses but they speak English really well too, at least from the exchange I heard between the waitress and an English-speaking patron.  

I already have my eye on the pork chops with rice (sounds fatty but heavenly) for my next trip here, and sometime I'll try the oyster pancake appetizer too.

The only drawback, which is a minor one, is that there's only a single restroom and it looks like a broom closet converted to a bathroom b/c it's so narrow. Really, I don't know how people with a slightly larger body habitus would squeeze into this, and the sink is tiny. But hey, you'll be spending most of your visit here chowing down, not in the bathroom, so all's well.

Post flower show lunch.  Ma Po Tofu, Scallion Pancakes, Soup Dumplings, and Stir Fried Eggplant were all delicious.  Come hungry as the portions are healthy and well priced.  Couldn't resist a Thai Iced Tea.
I ordered through grub hub and waited over an hour for my food only to be told that the restaurant cancelled my order without informing me and closed for the day. Unbelievable.

Excellent meal as usual, I had the chicken fried rice w/Mai Fun noodles. 
Meal was hot, chopsticks were clean, restaurant was nice and quiet even though it was full. 
Definitely a great place to eat.
The three cup chicken was fantastic. The noodle dish was a bit on the salty side.  Place was quiet and in a busy part of Chinatown. Scallion pancakes were good.

Best Taiwan style beef noodle soup (niu rou mian) in Mid Atlantic!  I've searched up and down East Coast from Boston to NYC to Washington DC, only this place is authentic with the right flavor.  Other Taiwanese food items on the menu were also amazing, including scallion pan cake, stir fried bamboo, etc.  The Indonesian dishes are good as well.  

The staff is friendly and helpful, food comes out fast.  The interior deco has been renovated and looks inviting.

I feel bad only giving this place 3 stars because the food was good, however I ordered the chicken chow mein, and there weren't any noodles at all. If they had just executed on that one particular item I would be on board all the way to give this place 4 stars.

But as I said, this place has it's pros for sure. A very extensive menu for a wide rage of tasty traditional Taiwanese foods, and what food I did get was well prepared, fresh, and very flavorful. But it's too much of an error for me to overlook unfortuantely.

This restaurant is absolutely amazing! After 26 years in Chinatown, they truly have perfected their cuisine. Talking to the owners, Julie and Michael, is a real pleasure. I asked what they would recommend and everything they chose was delicious! The ingredients and flavors were so fresh. I thoroughly enjoyed the scallion pancakes, fried dumplings (they also would have been good steamed as the filling was the best part), and the three flavor chicken. Try the watermelon and mango smoothies...only fresh fruit, ice and a tiny bit of sugar...so refreshing!

I only went here originally because I saw mention of Taiwanese beef noodle soup and pork chop. 

From perusing the menu, it seemed much more like standard Chinese fare that could be read in English. There was a whole lot of other things in Chinese that I obviously could not order because they had no translation. 

Anyway, the owner/waitress is super nice and was surprised I knew they had these items on their menu. Both of these dishes were just okay. I personally think I make a better Taiwanese pork chop at home and the beef noodle soup just wasn't like the ones I've had and loved back in CA. I did also return at a different time to try some things of their normal menu and again, it just tasted pretty typical. The stand out dish I did like is chicken in the clay pot.

The food was great, and the room was comfortable. We were the last group to leave and the owners were more than happy to wait for us to finish. The only downside is that the food was small portioned, especially for he price.

Good food for a decent price.  I normally go to imperial or shan pan kung ibut i tried this little joint and was thrilled with the quality and amount of food i got.  I always get to much food in chinatown but seriously, one combo dish can feed 2 people..and i can eat.

I was downtown and wanted some chinese food. i checked out several menus and nothing popped out at me. i was about to give up when i walked by empress garden. i ordered shrimp with chinese vegetables no water chestnuts as a take out. when i got home i was going to eat a lil bit and save some for later. well later never came. i ate the entire order. the food was soooo good i couldnt stop eating. the shrimp were a marvelous side. the vegetables melted in your mouth. the seasonings were on point. im going back and next time im eating in.
I ordered take out from here, and it took 1 hour and 25 minutes for it to be delivered. The weather was nice, clear roads - there was no reason why it should be late.

This is one of my favorite places to go eat in Philly Chinatown.  Even though I have eaten at this restaurant many times. I get the same thing every single time. 

Shanghai Style Rice Cakes with a side of fried pork chops.

It is simply awesome and I never get tired of it. The fried pork chops tastes great and its tastes different from other places that sell fried pork chops. It has a great crunch along with a light sauce to season it. And the soy sauced based sauteed rice cakes with vegetables is pretty awesome as well. 

The food may be a little greasy but a little grease is not a big deal to me. If you are one of those calorie counting salad munching health nazis, you might want to get something else.
Not impressed , left after soup. The menu was too basic and uninteresting. Hot tea had no flavor. Will not return.

On the window, I read: "Authentic Mandarin and Szechuan" and thought, "why not?" and walked in. It was around noon, and crowded.

Julia, Empress Garden's friendly owner, greeted me. We had a conversation on what was tasty and she ultimately recommended a Taiwanese noodle dish (C71 on the menu) to me, which I ordered to go. I mentioned that I've never been in her restaurant before, so when she said it was 24 years old, I was floored!

My dish of "spicy" (they weren't really spicy), dry Taiwanese noodles set me back $6.75, but kept me fed for hours. It was a generous portion of shredded string beans, salty soybeans, tofu, pepper flakes, pork (meat), bean sprouts, and white noodles. Did I mention it came out right away? Worth a try, stop in!

After a long day of work all I could think about is where I could take care of my noodle craving. As soon as Empress Garden came into mind I put my mind to ordering the Taiwanese beef noodle soup. The beef broth with the pickled veggies is so delicious with soft noodles. I also love the zajiangmian (Peiking noodles with meat sauce) which comes with crunchy string beans and tofu and ground meat. It's a bit spicy too :)
We also got the string beans which is perfectly crunchy - not soggy or burnt.
The service is always good and ever since they changed owners they have remodeled the place so it's more spacious than before.
I've also had their pork chops which are yummy. Their duck is decent too.
Also, come for their other taiwanese specialties such as the oyster pancake, yum!

I loved the scallion pancakes: super tasty, and in combo with sweet vinegar, it is fantastic! In addition, we ordered Jia Jia Mian (Peking Noodle with Meat Sauce), Braised Pork Feet over Rice and some Hunan Chicken. Each dish was yummy, dish sizes and prices are great. Plus, the kitchen works very fast.

In general, I have the feeling that this restaurant's dishes are a mixture of westernized Chinese and authentic Chinese cuisine which is not bad at all! :) Just don't be surprised of the food preparation/layout, as we were. Definitely worth a stop.

Underrated! Food was gross and unedible. I ordered orange chicken. It tasted old and spicy. I asked for a mild version of this dish. Someone else at the  table had an allergy of a garnish of a soup dish, he asked the wait staff if they could make the dish without the garnish.they said yes, and the dish came out with the garnish on it. The restaurant itsself was small and dirty. I ate nothing, and went to mcdonalds across the street for my edible food. NEVER AGAIN!!

Get their specials! This was the first time I've eaten Taiwanese beef noodle soup, but it gave me the same feeling as a good bowl of pho. 

I've passed by Empress Garden so many times while in Chinatown, but I finally decided to try it one cold night. Inside, it looks and is small, and what you see in the window is basically it. 

The Taiwanese beef noodle soup broth's was cloudy, the noodles were soft, and the beef was tender. The pickled collard greens was a surprising topping that added an interesting flavor to the savory soup. 

The spice must have been an oil because only the first few bites from the top were spicy, so I added some of the chili oil from the table. This was a whole other flavor which if you decide to try out Empress Garden, definitely try the chili oil.

Empress garden is one of the only (if not THE only) Taiwanese restaurant in the city.  They do have some more traditional Chinese entrees, as well, but I'd recommend trying some of the less common items if you go.  I've been several times, and have sampled the fried pork chop (really good), the meatball (a gelatinous rice ball with meat inside, and a tomato sauce on top) and a few of their soups and noodle dishes, which were all very good.  It's a nice place to go with an adventurous foodie group to try some new dishes that may be less common that what you'd find in Chinatown.

I always get the Indonesian Fried Rice and General Tso's Chicken both extra spicy. That's comfort food for me. Even when I get the food to go, it's still delicious. My Indonesian friends all claim the Indo fried rice here is the best in the city. Their Taiwanese food is decent too and they have good lunch specials.

We visited Empress Garden on spring Saturday afternoon around 18.00 Hrs. The place was clean and had a moderate crowd. We were quickly seated and our server brought out tea and iced water almost immediately. Our server then disappeared for 15-20 minutes before taking our order. We then waited ten minutes for our soups to arrive. I found the hot and sour soup to only match its name in one adjective: the temperature was hot. The soup had a very thick consistency and very oily. The soup was rather bland with no flavor. My dining companions agreed that their wonton soup also was oily and bland and one remarked he thought the meat in his was "off" which he did report to the server. We only consumed about half of our soups before pushing them away.

   Our server removed the half consumed soup and listened to the report of bd meat in the wonton. Fifteen minutes later she brought out our main courses. I ordered the General Tso's chicken with a vegetable roll, our server said the substitution was no problem, as I have a seafood allergy. My companions also ordered a General Tso's and sweet and sour chicken, all with shrimp rolls. 

   I found my General Tso's also to be rather bland: the sauce was sweet but no "kick" or orange flavor to it. My companions stated the sweet and sour chicken was okay but nothing rave about. They also agreed that the General Tso's was bland and uninteresting. The final straw was when one of the companions consumed their shrimp roll only to find out it was my vegetable roll. I'm glad I didn't immediately bite in to my egg roll as I did not have my Epipen with me and spending a Saturday night in the emergency room is not fun.

   We chose the Empress Garden based upon Yelp reviews so maybe we got an off night or the place is not consistent. Either way we won't be going back.

I was in the mood for fried rice. There are many options in the area but I decided on Empress Garden based on reviewer comments and pictures.  

The store front was very hole-in-the-wall which is fine with me because I tend to have better experiences with small places as opposed to hyped-up elaborate establishments.

I walked in and was greeted by an employee who offered me a table but I said I would like to make a to-go order and he quickly gave me a menu and asked if I had any questions.  I placed my to-go order of pork fried rice extra spicy with extra veggies.  The price was surprisingly low so I made sure to clarify that I was charged correctly for the full order and not half or lunch portion and he confirmed that the full order is correctly around $7.

I helped myself to a seat as I waited.  The dining area is small, perhaps 10 to 12 tables and there were no other customers present but I was there in the middle afternoon on Tuesday.

My to-go order was ready in 5 minutes.  The rice was packed in a typical styrofoam food box put into a plastic shopping bag along with chopsticks and a plastic fork and spoon.  It did not include soy sauce, hot mustard, etc so keep that in mind if you like to put soy sauce on your food.

The fried rice was pretty good.  It was a bit dry but I contribute that to the fact that I took it to-go and reheated it.  There were hardly any veggies despite me asking for extra veggies but the meal was still good.  The flavor was good and the spice level was noticeable but not what I would consider hot.  I prefer the larger chunks of pork in fried rice but this one had those smaller bits of chewy pork that are perhaps the size of peas.  There was a generous portion of pork which was very satisfying.

Overall, I rate this place as pretty good.  I am satisfied with my fried rice meal.  The menu had other dishes that looked very good so I would be happy to eat here again if I had the opportunity.

Great rice dishes and Taiwanese favorites! The braised pork belly with tofu and the fried pork chops are some of the best quick meals around. Decent beef noodle soup as well, especially on a cold winter night. A chinatown staple that you should check out!

Enjoy!

We went for diner with 5 persons. The food was good. The portions are pretty big. They don't serve the diners the same time. So one person was almost ready when the last person got her food. The waitress was not interested, and the menu could not be adjusted a little bit. Taste of the food is good and it looked fresh. That's why I give 3 stars.

Not sure if they are/ have been under new management... I went in and the pictures that are usually hanging on the wall are no longer there... Customer service went downhill.

Ordered my fried pork chop to go. The service over the phone is awful. It's not my fault you speak broken english missy! 

Arrived home and opened the pork chop and could tell right away it wasn't fresh. It looked like it  was poorly over fried, tough and chewy. Could've possibly been leftovers from the looks of it. 

I've never been disappointed with my take outs here. Everything use to be fresh and delicious. But now i don't know if I'll ever come  back.

I've been here a lot. I bring my family here. I bring my friends here. Being Taiwanese, I feel that real Taiwanese offerings are pretty scarce in Philadelphia (hint hint, someone open up a new Taiwanese joint already sheesh!). Sometimes I crave the food that you can just pick up from some random street cart in Taipei. Anyway, so I scoured the internet for Taiwanese places in Philadelphia, and if anyone has another suggestion for one, please let me know. That's how I stumbled across Empress Garden a couple years ago. I've been going fairly regularly since.

They've recently remodeled, and the restaurant actually looks much nicer (although I was sad when they were closed for remodeling). There are a few staples I always get:

- Scallion pancakes - Even though the ones here aren't really super authentic, they're just really good! They're deep fried, and that fish and vinegar sauce it comes with is really good. I usually get two orders, and if I'm sharing with friends I secretly hog it. 

- 3 Cups Chicken - This dish should have the bone in (for flavor), basil, ginger, and that sweet sticky soy sauce. This is really quite addicting. The flavors are perfect in combination.

- Fried pork chop - The ones here are very juicy and have a crispy outside. 

- Jah Jang Mein - It's Taiwanese style, so for the Koreans out there, don't expect zucchini and black tarry sauce. It's savory, meaty, flavorful, and really hits the spot. I'm not sure if the noodles are house made, but they definitely have that chewy spring to them (for those who know what I'm talking about, very "Q").

- Beef noodle soup - This also has that authentic Taiwanese developed flavor. Again, the noodles are so good here.

They also do offer a lot of Taiwanese street foods including oyster pancake, Taiwanese meatball with glutinous rice wrap ("bah wan"), and other tasty offerings.

Finally, if you don't speak Chinese, can't read it, or don't have a Chinese friend to bring with you to the restaurant, choose something off the above list. There are 2 menus here, the English menu and the Chinese menu (which has more of the authentic tasty food). I would hate for you to come here and end up with General Tso's chicken.

So this is the place to go for Taiwanese food in Philly Chinatown. When I walked by the window, 2 dishes stood out to me. So of course, I ordered 3. This is the 3 cups chicken. I didn't know why this dish was called that and so I looked it up and apparently it's because you make it with 1 cup of rice wine, 1 cup of sesame oil and 1 cup of soy sauce. Out of the three dishes we had, this one was the most difficult to eat because of all the chicken bones.

This is one of my all time favorite dishes, eggplant with ground pork in garlic sauce.  Even when I got the to go bag, I could smell the eggplant dish beckoning me to the back seat. My boyfriend wasn't too pleased that I had killed the new car smell with Chinese food. Oh well!

This is one of my favorite spots in Chinatown that serves authentic Taiwanese cuisine. I took my family here recently when they were visiting and they were big fans. My parents grew up in Taiwan and even they commented on how impressed they were with every dish.
We ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup, oyster pancake, triple stir fried, salt and pepper pork chop, and beef chow fun. Highly recommend the beef noodle soup- so many tender chunks of meat, substantial noodles, and the broth was flavourful with the right amount of spicy. The salt and pepper pork chop was delicious, perfectly crispy and savoury. Beef chow fun was standard, and we also finished the triple stir fried and oyster pancake in no time.
Side note: we were seated next to a table of foreigners that ordered fried rice and wonton/egg drop soup and it truly saddened my soul to know they were missing out on the real winning dishes. 
Definitely stop by here next time you're in Chinatown!

This place is no longer good! They have new ownership and are no longer Taiwanese-owned. The Cantonese owners said they have the same cooks, but you could clearly taste the difference between the current and previous food. The oyster omlete was watery and had a strong fishy taste and the fried pork chop was battered diffently that left a bad taste in my mouth. Unfortunately, there aren't any Taiwanese restaurants in the region that serve this type of food.

Appearances can be quite deceiving, as we know all too well from Macbeth. From the outside, this doesn't look like much but it is a treasure trove of authentic Taiwanese dishes that are simply too die for (or at least worth the Chinatown parking charge and rush hour traffic on the good ole I-76).  The Taiwanese beef noodle soup is the most popular dish, and is well deserving of its reputation.  Perfect on a cold day.  Also be sure to try the pork chops with the Shanghainese rice  cakes.  The basil/three cup chicken is pretty good.  Just stay away from takeout dishes because those tend to be well, takeout-like, for lack of a more precise description.  If you're in Chinatown, you need to stop by.  My family has been coming here for the past 17 years, and it is still one of our favorite restaurants.  I've brought friends from school here and even the Californians find this place to be authentic.  That, too me at least, says a lot.

everything is good. but if I had a choice to order one dish and one dish only, it would be the braised pork with tofu. fatty pieces of pork belly braised in a sweet soy with fried tofu. it is that good people! ask for a few extra bowls of rice to finish the dish

Kind of a small place. Usually packed during peak hours, but has takeout. The waiters don't really speak Chinese, but the food is very authentic. Some items are Taiwanese but I think most are more a mix of different regions. I like the scallion pancakes and noodle soup. Probably one of the better places in Chinatown.

Met a friend here for lunch today. It wasn't the restaurant she had in mind but it was crazy cold outside and we both were hungry. 

Serendipity. 

The food was delicious and the staff was friendly. Prices were very reasonable and I'd definitely go back.

I'm spoiled by the best Taiwanese food in Taiwan so there is just no comparison to the real thing.  even thou this place is suppose to be the philly branch of the original tawanese place in taiwan.

- oyster omelet, a signature taiwanese food stand specialty.  it's comfort food for me, the only other place i've had it in the east coast is in maryland.   it's not too bad here.  One day I'll try nyc
We like this place.  The ingredients were fresh, dishes were well-prepared and the price was good.

In continuing to check out the diversity of restaurants in Chinatown, decided that I was in the mood for Taiwanese food and came here around brunch time. The restaurant can be easy to miss as its surrounded by a plethora of bakeries and other restaurants in the heart of Chinatown but don't sleep on this place!

Got the traditional Taiwanese pork chop, Taiwanese noodle, and the pork and mustard greens sour soup. As my friend pointed out, although the beef noodle soup is the most popular of Taiwanese dishes this sour mustard green pork soup is a little known traditional delight and actually sold at very few restaurants. However, it was delicious and a lot lighter than most beef based soups. Definitely great for a hot day add a huge portion for less than $7 per bowl. Same with the pork chop, which was tender in the center with a crispy, seasoned crust. 

Finally, the stereotype with a lot of cheap Chinese restaurants in Chinatown is the poor service but that couldn't be further from the case here! The lady who served us was so kind and warm and I liked that they played Chinese music in the background - really gave it that authentic feel haha. Would recommend, come and eat here!

Came on Wednesday night. Quick service. Good food. Hits the spot. The food is authentic and service is quick. They're one of the few places in Philly that serves oyster pancakes! 
Some of my go to dishes are:
Scallion Pancake, beef chow fun, beef noodle soup, pan fried noodles.
